rev.comment: /* Easter eggs and April Fool's Day jokes */
rev.diff:
Line 123: Line 123:
Google's services contain a number of [[Easter egg (virtual)|Easter eggs]]; for instance, the Language Tools page offers the search interface in the [[Swedish Chef]]'s "Bork bork bork," [[Pig Latin]], "Hacker" (actually [[leetspeak]]), [[Elmer Fudd]], and [[Klingon language|Klingon]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/language_tools?hl=en Language Tools]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on January 24, 2007.</ref> <!--When asked how to get from a location in the U.S. to a location in Europe (or vice versa), Google Maps will provide directions that include an instruction to "Swim across the Atlantic Ocean."<ref name="atlantic">"[http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&saddr=North+America&daddr=Germany Google Maps]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on May 2, 2007.</ref>--> In addition, the search engine calculator provides the [[Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe, and Everything]] from [[Douglas Adams]]' ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]''.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/search?q=answer+to+life+the+universe+and+everything Google Search Results for 'answer to life the universe and everything']." ''Google.'' Retrieved on January 24, 2007.</ref> As Googleâs search box can be used as a unit converter (as well as a calculator), some non-standard units are built in, such as the [[Smoot]]. A newly discovered easter egg is the spell-checker's result for the properly spelled word "recursion". The spell-checker built into Google search returns "Did you mean: recursion?" in a recursive link back to the same page.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?q=recursion Google results for "recursion"]</ref> In Google Maps, searching for directions between places, such as Los Angeles and Tokyo results in one direction being "kayak across the Pacific Ocean." Google also routinely modifies its logo in accordance with various holidays or special events throughout the year, such as Christmas, Mother's Day, or the birthdays of various notable individuals.<ref name="google_holiday">"[http://www.google.com/intl/en/holidaylogos.html Holiday logos]." ''Google''. Retrieved on May 21, 2007.</ref> Other logo switches are based on search terms. For instance, if the term "[[ASCII art|ascii art]]" (all lower-case required) <!-- Experimentation with Google search box December 21, 2009. Citation link worked, directions didn't. Case seems to be the key. --> is searched, an ASCII art version of the Google logo will appear next to the search box.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=ascii+art&btnG=Search&aq=f&oq=&aqi= Google search results for "ascii art"]</ref>
Google's services contain a number of [[Easter egg (virtual)|Easter eggs]]; for instance, the Language Tools page offers the search interface in the [[Swedish Chef]]'s "Bork bork bork," [[Pig Latin]], "Hacker" (actually [[leetspeak]]), [[Elmer Fudd]], and [[Klingon language|Klingon]].<ref>"[http://www.google.com/language_tools?hl=en Language Tools]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on January 24, 2007.</ref> <!--When asked how to get from a location in the U.S. to a location in Europe (or vice versa), Google Maps will provide directions that include an instruction to "Swim across the Atlantic Ocean."<ref name="atlantic">"[http://maps.google.com/maps?f=d&hl=en&saddr=North+America&daddr=Germany Google Maps]." ''Google.'' Retrieved on May 2, 2007.</ref>--> In addition, the search engine calculator provides the [[Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe, and Everything]] from [[Douglas Adams]]' ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]''.<ref>"[http://www.google.com/search?q=answer+to+life+the+universe+and+everything Google Search Results for 'answer to life the universe and everything']." ''Google.'' Retrieved on January 24, 2007.</ref> As Googleâs search box can be used as a unit converter (as well as a calculator), some non-standard units are built in, such as the [[Smoot]]. A newly discovered easter egg is the spell-checker's result for the properly spelled word "recursion". The spell-checker built into Google search returns "Did you mean: recursion?" in a recursive link back to the same page.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?q=recursion Google results for "recursion"]</ref> In Google Maps, searching for directions between places, such as Los Angeles and Tokyo results in one direction being "kayak across the Pacific Ocean." Google also routinely modifies its logo in accordance with various holidays or special events throughout the year, such as Christmas, Mother's Day, or the birthdays of various notable individuals.<ref name="google_holiday">"[http://www.google.com/intl/en/holidaylogos.html Holiday logos]." ''Google''. Retrieved on May 21, 2007.</ref> Other logo switches are based on search terms. For instance, if the term "[[ASCII art|ascii art]]" (all lower-case required) <!-- Experimentation with Google search box December 21, 2009. Citation link worked, directions didn't. Case seems to be the key. --> is searched, an ASCII art version of the Google logo will appear next to the search box.<ref>[http://www.google.com/search?hl=en&q=ascii+art&btnG=Search&aq=f&oq=&aqi= Google search results for "ascii art"]</ref>
  +
During FIFA World Cup 2010, search queries like 'world cup', 'fifa', etc. will cause the ''Goooo...gle'' page indicator at the bottom of every result page to read ''Goooo...al!'' instead.
